The "Prevention of School Violence Act of 1999" emphasizes the importance of ensuring students' safety in schools, especially in light of recent tragic incidents. It highlights the need for continuous efforts to enhance school safety and create a conducive learning environment for students. There is a growing urgency to understand the causes of student violence and find effective strategies to prevent it in schools. Establishment of National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence, known as the "National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence". Membership of the Commission. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence is composed of 11 members appointed by various officials, including the Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, Minority Leader of the Senate, Secretary of Education, Attorney General, and Secretary of Health and Human Services. The appointing officials consult to ensure qualifications are met for individuals appointed to the National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence, including expertise in child and adolescent behavior, dealing with at-risk children, and school safety and violence issues. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence appoints individuals with expertise in child and adolescent behavior, at-risk children, school safety, and violence issues. Panel members include professionals in psychology, psychiatry, mental health, social work, school safety, counseling, and juvenile justice, as well as parents, to address the impact of violent incidents on the learning experience. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence consults experts from education, criminal justice, behavioral science, school safety, psychology, organizations dealing with at-risk youth, and members of the public who come in contact with at-risk youth. The National Commission on the Prevention of School Violence includes members from various fields such as public health, statistics, criminology, and education. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for decision-making. All appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The appointment of officers must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. If an officer fails to make an appointment, the Chairman or Ranking Minority Member of specific committees can act on their behalf for the Speaker and Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, as well as the Majority Leader and Minority Leader of the Senate. The Commission members are entitled to one vote each, vacancies do not affect its powers, no additional pay is given, and the initial meeting must occur within 40 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study school violence incidents, interviewing perpetrators, families, friends, teachers, and counselors for insights. Findings and recommendations will focus on the extent, patterns, and root causes of school violence, key factors, relationships between perpetrators and victims, and family dynamics. The Commission will study school violence incidents, interviewing perpetrators, families, friends, teachers, and counselors for insights on prevention strategies and recommendations to ensure student safety and a high-quality learning environment. The Commission will provide a detailed report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members for submission to the President and Congress. SEC. 5. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from Federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission, under the Freedom of Information Act, can request information from Federal agencies. The head of any agency can provide facilities, services, and personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission can enter into contracts for research, appoint staff, and set compensation as needed to fulfill its duties under the Act. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff as needed, with compensation not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is authorized to appropriate up to $650,000 for its expenses, with funds remaining available until expended or one year after its termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
